title: Checkpoint: Quarter 4 — Geometry, Data, and Cumulative
description: Assessment covering geometry, measurement, data interpretation, patterns, and cumulative skills from all units.

remediationStrategy.description: Students scoring below threshold receive focused reteaching on their weakest geometry, data, and pattern skills. Remediation bridges concrete models (grid paper, rulers, real graphs) to abstract reasoning.

clusters.reteachFocus: Walk around the shape, add every side, watch for missing sides on irregular shapes, perimeter is always a length (one unit, not squared)
Area = length × width, count unit squares on grid paper first, area uses square units, distinguish from perimeter
Right angle = 90° (square corner), acute < 90°, obtuse > 90°, angles on a straight line sum to 180°, use a corner of paper as a right-angle checker
Count sides and angles, identify parallel and perpendicular sides, quadrilateral family tree (square → rectangle → parallelogram), sort shapes by properties not appearance
Customary vs metric, converting within the same system (12 in = 1 ft, 100 cm = 1 m), multiply to go smaller → bigger count, divide to go bigger → smaller count
Read axis labels and scale carefully, bar height = value, line plot Xs above number line, always check what each axis represents before answering
Compare bars or data points, find totals by adding, find differences by subtracting, 'how many more' = subtraction, draw conclusions from data
Find what changes each step (add, subtract, multiply), write the rule in words first then with numbers, use the rule to predict future terms, input/output tables
Unknown = a number we need to find, use a letter or box, set up the equation from the word problem, use inverse operations to solve, check by plugging back in

assessmentProblems.question: A rectangle has a length of 12 cm and a width of 5 cm. What is the perimeter of the rectangle?
Jayla wants to put a fence around her rectangular garden. The garden is 18 feet long and 9 feet wide. How many feet of fencing does she need?
A rectangular rug is 7 feet long and 4 feet wide. What is the area of the rug?
Mr. Torres is tiling a rectangular kitchen floor that is 15 feet long and 8 feet wide. Each tile covers 1 square foot and costs $2. What is the total cost to tile the entire floor?
assessmentProblems.answer: Area = 15 × 8 = 120 square feet. Total cost = 120 × $2 = $240. He needs 120 tiles and will spend $240.

assessmentProblems.question: Look at these three angles: Angle A opens as wide as a book barely cracked open. Angle B looks like the corner of a piece of paper. Angle C opens wider than a book laid flat. Classify each angle as acute, right, or obtuse.
assessmentProblems.answer: Angle A is acute (less than 90° — a small opening). Angle B is a right angle (exactly 90° — a square corner). Angle C is obtuse (greater than 90° — opens wider than a right angle).

assessmentProblems.question: Two angles sit on a straight line. One angle measures 115°. What is the measure of the other angle? What type of angle is it — acute, right, or obtuse?
assessmentProblems.answer: Angles on a straight line add up to 180°. The other angle = 180° − 115° = 65°. Since 65° is less than 90°, it is an acute angle.

assessmentProblems.question: Name a shape that has exactly 4 sides, 4 right angles, and all sides the same length. Then name a shape that has 4 sides and 4 right angles but does NOT have all sides the same length. What makes these two shapes different?
assessmentProblems.answer: A square has 4 sides, 4 right angles, and all sides equal. A rectangle has 4 sides and 4 right angles but opposite sides are equal (not all four). The difference is that a square has all equal sides while a rectangle has two pairs of equal sides.

assessmentProblems.question: A parallelogram has opposite sides that are parallel and equal in length. Is a rectangle a parallelogram? Is a triangle a parallelogram? Explain both answers using the properties.
assessmentProblems.answer: Yes, a rectangle is a parallelogram because it has two pairs of parallel sides and opposite sides are equal in length. It is a special parallelogram with all right angles. No, a triangle is NOT a parallelogram because it has only 3 sides (a parallelogram must have exactly 4) and it does not have two pairs of parallel sides.

assessmentProblems.question: Convert: How many inches are in 4 feet? (Remember: 1 foot = 12 inches.)
A bookshelf is 3 feet 7 inches tall. A doorway is 50 inches tall. Will the bookshelf fit through the doorway? Show your work.
assessmentProblems.answer: Convert the bookshelf to inches: 3 feet = 36 inches, so 3 feet 7 inches = 36 + 7 = 43 inches. Compare: 43 inches < 50 inches. Yes, the bookshelf will fit through the doorway with 7 inches to spare.

assessmentProblems.question: A bar graph shows the number of books read by four students in March: Aisha — 8 books, Ben — 5 books, Carlos — 10 books, Dana — 7 books. How many books did all four students read in total?
assessmentProblems.answer: Add all the values: 8 + 5 + 10 + 7 = 30 books total.

assessmentProblems.question: Using the same data — Aisha: 8 books, Ben: 5 books, Carlos: 10 books, Dana: 7 books — answer these questions: (a) How many more books did Carlos read than Ben? (b) If Aisha reads 4 more books in April, will she have read more total books than Carlos did in March?
assessmentProblems.answer: (a) Carlos read 10 − 5 = 5 more books than Ben. (b) Aisha in March + April = 8 + 4 = 12 books. Carlos in March = 10 books. 12 > 10, so yes, Aisha will have read more than Carlos.

assessmentProblems.question: Find the rule and give the next three numbers in this pattern: 3, 7, 11, 15, 19, ___, ___, ___.
assessmentProblems.answer: The rule is add 4 each time (7 − 3 = 4, 11 − 7 = 4, 15 − 11 = 4). Next three: 19 + 4 = 23, 23 + 4 = 27, 27 + 4 = 31. The pattern continues: 23, 27, 31.

assessmentProblems.question: An input-output table shows: Input 2 → Output 7, Input 4 → Output 13, Input 6 → Output 19, Input 10 → Output ___. Find the rule and use it to find the missing output.
assessmentProblems.answer: Look at the pattern: 2 → 7 (multiply by 3, add 1: 2×3+1=7), 4 → 13 (4×3+1=13), 6 → 19 (6×3+1=19). The rule is: Output = Input × 3 + 1. For input 10: 10 × 3 + 1 = 31. The missing output is 31.

assessmentProblems.question: Mia has some stickers. She gives 14 stickers to her friend and has 23 stickers left. Write an equation using a letter for the unknown number, and solve it. How many stickers did Mia start with?
assessmentProblems.answer: Let s = the number of stickers Mia started with. Equation: s − 14 = 23. Solve: s = 23 + 14 = 37. Mia started with 37 stickers. Check: 37 − 14 = 23 ✓.

answerKeys.cq4-5: A = acute, B = right, C = obtuse
answerKeys.cq4-7: Square (all sides equal, 4 right angles); Rectangle (opposite sides equal, 4 right angles)
answerKeys.cq4-8: Yes, a rectangle is a parallelogram; No, a triangle is not
